A national memorial service in Paris today paid homage to the victims of the November 13 attacks.

A military band and orchestra and a choir were among the performances at the hour-long ceremony.
It was held in the courtyard of the imposing historic Invalide military complex in the heart of Paris, where France's national heroes and fallen military are usually honored.
The symbolism was clear.
President Francois Hollande said honor the martyrs who died in the Paris attacks as heroes of the nation.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking French).
For 11 minutes, one by one, the names and ages of the dead were read out loud and their photographs projected on a giant screen.
The eldest was 68, the youngest, just 17.
Most were under the age of 35, says Hollande, adding that the youth of France has been struck at its core.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking French).
Hollande says this generation has become the public face of France.

He says those killed were out for a Friday evening of music, food, drink, sport and good company at a concert venue, at restaurants and bars when gunmen opened fire and near a main stadium on the outskirts of Paris.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking French).
Hollande says those responsible for the killings are enemies, an army of fanatic driven by hatred.

Survivors, some wounded and in wheelchairs and even stretchers, and families of victims sat on one side of the esplanade on a crisp and bracing Paris morning, with giant French blue, white and red flags fluttering overhead.

The refugee crisis in Europe has, not surprisingly, become an issue influencing voters.
Poland is the latest example.

It appears that the Law and Justice Party will have the absolute majority - the first time that's happened since the end of communism in Poland in 1989.
To talk about the implications of this election, we're joined now by The Wall Street Journal's Martin Sobczyk in Warsaw.
Welcome to the program.
Hi.
Thanks for having me.
And this election is being called historic.
Why?
It is historic because for the first time, a single political party won more than half of seats in the lower house of Polish Parliament.
And also, and perhaps even more importantly, it happened at a very sensitive time in Europe's history, really, when it's faced with the migrant crisis, the Russia-Ukraine crisis in the East.
And the Law and Justice Party comes in with very feisty language, sometimes very politically incorrect language, and the change is happening at an extremely important time.
We see the market's up slightly today.
Does that mean that, indeed, the markets can correct themselves without a gigantic government bailout?
So today, no, obviously this is not something that I think the Bush administration could be trusted to use properly.

E.R., John is basically saying look, the law in and of itself is not that bad, it's the question of how this government would implement it.
But laws exists after government's transition.
So what do you think about that?
Professor E.R.
SHIPP (Journalism, Hofstra University): Well, I think the common denominator here is the phrase dangerous enemy alien.

And back in the World War II era, Japanese-Americans, meaning the children of Japanese immigrants, were considered to be dangerous enemy aliens, though they never set foot in Japan and they were all Americans as far as they were concerned.

The parallel is striking with what's going on now with Muslims, among others, who are being challenged as potentially dangerous enemy aliens and subjected to all kinds of deprivations because of that.

Whether it's the Bush administration or another administration that may follow, I think we need to keep history in mind and try to figure out a way to define what it means to be in the United States, a place that we've always lauded as being a melting pot or a big stew, but to deal with out fears post-9/11, and I think that's what's coming to bear here.

Jeff, the ruling that basically these Japanese friend-of-the-court brief filers are responding to says that the executive, the president, is free to single out nationals of a particular country; but it also went on to basically say that you could single out Arab Muslims because it was unclear what countries the people who perpetrated the crime were actually from, or they were form multiple countries.
That's a pretty broad mandate, does that bother you?
Yeah, I think the broadness of it is exactly what bothers me.
Going back to something that John said in terms of how do you specify particularly how this law is put down, and what E.R.
was saying about what actually makes a dangerous enemy alien versus somebody that doesn't fall into that category.

And when you broaden that category our to Arab Muslims and attach that to the word terror, then I think you make it so broad that it can't be specified in a way that's not going to be offensive to a large number of people.

I think that Mr. Sui(ph) and the other friends of the court should be commended for jumping into this conversation and having this conversation because many people have drawn that parallel between the Japanese-American interment and the treatment of Muslims after 9/11.
I'd argue that this policy now might be even worse than the Japanese internment simply because we're supposed to be more evolved.
Now, in terms of how words are used, when we talk out dangerous enemy aliens I think what we're dealing with is what America has dealt with from the start, and that is practice versus policy.
The Constitution of the United States is fine as written; it did not need to be amended because all men are created equal.
But it was amended because African-Americans were not considered men.
But technically, if we're considered men or women from the beginning, we need not amend that.
So I think that, once again, dangerous enemy aliens is just a broad term that can be invoked at any particular time to practice racial profiling, and none of us like that, I don't think.
And, you know, all that is very true.

But I feel moved to just add that despite the fact that we have to be vigilant about all those things, we also have to remember that these are different times than the founding fathers could have imagined, than we could have imagined even 20 years ago.
And there are aspects of these things that I do think demand creative thinking.
And so, for example, let's say I live in Jersey City, you take a train to New York.
There was actually a plot that was hatched to blow up the tunnel that leads from New Jersey to New York.
They didn't do it.
No one was sure whether they were actually going to do it.
But in terms of the Internet and what they were recorded saying, it was something that they certainly seemed to be cooking up.

Now I'm no legal theorist, but is true that in a situation like this, when we consider whether or not the people who were going to do this should have been detained for longer than a week or two, that we should start talking about the founding father and profiling and African-Americans and what happened to the Japanese, et cetera.
When all those concepts were developed there was no such thing as the technology that allow us to figure out what people may or may not be doing now.
That's just what I want to throw in.
In terms of what you're saying, though, in your example you had concrete evidence of somebody plotting something.
You weren't saying you were going to round up all Arab Muslims.
That is true.

And, Jeff, you have a movie background as someone who is a writer and an actor.
What's interesting is that the Denzel Washington character has to kind of balance his general feelings about civil liberties with the safety of the city.

What makes the Samaritan empathetic to the guy who's been knocked in the head and laid on the wayside is the fact that the Samaritan people were treated like crap forever, so he understands what that feels like.
So he helps people in that position.
I don't think African-Americans would join this at this day and time unless some situation occurred where there was racial profiling of black males.
Or, say for instance, a 12-year-old black girl was found on the Internet plotting to try to get other 12-year-old black girls across the nation to go their middle schools and blow up something.

And then when they started knocking on our doors, getting our 12 to 13-year-old black girls out and putting them in a pen or taking them downtown for questioning, I think then we would be filing a friend of the court.

We need to realize that we're not quite that far away from that, and an injustice anywhere, of course, is a threat to justice everywhere.

E.R., there's another case that is about confinement - a very different kind of confinement.
Twenty-seven-year-old Robert Daniels is in jail, but he hasn't committed any crime.
He's got drug-resistant TB - tuberculosis - that's considered untreatable.
Now the county authorities in Phoenix, Arizona took Daniels into custody last July because they say that he hasn't been taking precautions to avoid infecting others.
He hasn't been wearing a mask in public, for example.
Daniels says, hey, let me out.
And health experts say that situations like this could happen more and more with the spread of new and newly drug-resistant diseases around the world.
So is it fair to keep someone in jail for being sick?
That's a very interesting case.
It's not clear that if this young man wore a mask in public that that would be sufficient to protect the rest of the public from his strain of tuberculosis.
So that part of this story is a little bit murky, as far as I'm concerned.
It is, though, raising concerns about the potential of many of us developing these various diseases, if you will, that resist some of the antibiotics that we're so accustomed to taking.
What do you do?
How far do you go?
Will be build camps for people like the lepers colonies kind of thing?
I hope we don't go that far.
But it's very much still up in the air in the medical community as to how to treat this problem.
In the story of the tuberculosis guy it's not completely clear whether he has said that he would wear the mask if he were released.

I think most of us would feel that if he's being kept confined because he didn't wear the mask when he didn't know he was supposed to, and then he said, okay, I'll wear it and still he's being kept between four walls, then that's obviously not the right thing.

If on the other hand he's the sort of person who's given to acting up or thinks that it's part of his civil rights to not wear the mask despite the fact that he has a deadly disease, then that's something different.
But I think most people would feel that no one has a civil right to walk around killing other people with their breath.
If it goes that far, then the tragedy is that certain people are going to have to be what used to be called ""quarantined."" You know, words are interesting.

Hopefully that would be with - just as with the Arab case as we were hypothetically talking about - a very small number of people.
Jeff, there is a precedent for this.
Texas put 17 tuberculosis patients into involuntary quarantine this year.
And I think that there's the word quarantine and then there's also involuntary.
There's no question that drug-resistant tuberculosis is extremely virulent.
People with compromised immune systems like people with HIV or other medical conditions will be very much susceptible to this.
